citation.article-title: Kribbella karoonensis sp. nov. and Kribbella swartbergensis sp. nov., isolated from soil from the Western Cape, South Africa
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Kribbella karoonensis sp. nov.
Kribbella karoonensis (ka.roo.nen′sis. N.L. fem. adj. karoonensis pertaining to the Karoo Desert National Botanical Garden in Worcester, South Africa).
Gram-positive.
Aerobic.
Aerial mycelium is pale cream/white and the vegetative hyphae are cream/yellow on inorganic salts/starch agar (ISP 4).
Hyphae fragment into rod-shaped elements in broth and on agar.
No diffusible pigments are produced on glycerol/asparagine agar (ISP 5).
Melanin pigment is not produced on peptone/yeast extract/iron agar (ISP 6) or tyrosine agar (ISP 7).
Nitrate is reduced.
Catalase-positive.
Produces H2S.

Utilizes d(−)-fructose, d(+)-glucose, glycerol, myo-inositol, lactose, d-mannitol, d(+)-mannose, raffinose, l(+)-rhamnose, sodium succinate, sucrose and d(+)-xylose as sole carbon sources, with doubtful growth on adonitol, l(+)-arabinose, maltose, sodium acetate, sodium benzoate, sodium citrate and sodium lactate.
Grows at 20–37 °C.
Grows at pH 5, 7 and 9.
Aesculin, arbutin and starch are hydrolysed.
Degrades adenine, casein, gelatin, hypoxanthine and l-tyrosine.
Produces weak degradation of Tween 80 after 14 days, but the type strain grows poorly on this test medium.
Grows well on ISP 2 medium in the presence of 2 % NaCl, with weak growth in the presence of 3 and 4 % NaCl.
Grows in the presence of carbenicillin disodium salt (100 μg ml−1), chloramphenicol (20 μg ml−1), cycloheximide (10 μg ml−1), erythromycin (10 μg ml−1) and streptomycin sulphate (10 μg ml−1).
Cell-wall peptidoglycan contains ll-diaminopimelic acid and glycine (chemotype I).
The whole-cell sugars are ribose and mannose.

The type strain Q41T (=NRRL B-24425T=DSM 17344T), was isolated from soil collected from the base of a giant quiver tree, Aloe pillansii, growing in the Karoo Desert National Botanical Garden, Worcester, Western Cape province, South Africa.
